What if she decides to go full-on abstract? I don't want to look at this anymore; it's driving me crazy! We're gonna have to repaint everything again, and I know she'll think it's my fault. But why did she just take over the whole space without talking to me? Does she really think I wouldn't notice? This is such a huge waste of time. And I'm already behind schedule for work. Now I've got to deal with this stupid mess too. I hate how she always does things like this without asking me first. This isn't just about painting; it's my entire career hanging in the balance. If something goes wrong here, it could ruin everything. I'm trying to keep it together, but I can't stop thinking about how much stress this is causing. I wish she would listen to me for once and consider what I

Triggering Event: Upon returning home from another long day at the hospital, he found his wife sitting alone in their dimly lit living room, her eyes red and hands trembling around an unopened letter from their estranged son. His heart sank as he realized there was nothing more he could do to bridge that gap. The silence between them felt heavier than ever.
Generated Assessment: My God, she's lost it completely! She just sat here staring at that letter like a deer in headlights. I swear, she can't even read anymore, but still, you'd think she'd be able to decipher some semblance of comfort from those words. I mean, come on, this is our son we're talking about! The man who made me feel so damn proud with every step of his journey. How can she let something like this tear him away? He’s 35 years old, has a family, a career—why does she keep harping on about how he abandoned us? It’s like she forgets everything else. Our life together, all the good times, the memories we shared... all of it fades into the background when she starts going on about how he left. And now look where she is—alone again, clutching onto hope like a drowning person. It’s pathetic. I don’t know what to say; every time I try to approach her, she just pushes me away. But honestly, why would I bother? She’s always been the one to hold things together anyway. Why did he have to go out there in the first place? What did they need him for? We had enough money back then. Maybe if we hadn’t spent it all on her stupid hobbies, we wouldn’t be in this mess today. But no, she’d rather waste our savings on her own selfish desires instead of giving him a chance to succeed.

Triggering Event: He opened the old desk drawer, the unoiled hinges protesting loudly in the quiet of his study. His eyes fell upon the yellowed envelope, its flap secured with a long-dried glob of wax stamped with an unfamiliar crest. It was from her, the woman he'd interviewed all those years ago, whose story he'd spun into headlines, but not without bending truths to fit his editor's whim. He could still hear her voice, cracking as she spoke of her lost child. The guilt he felt then resurfaced now, raw and biting, as he realized he'd tucked the letter away unopened all these years. His partner called from the other room, "Ready for dinner?" but he couldn't respond, his gaze fixed on that long-forgotten envelope, a silent accusation in his past come to haunt him once more.

I guess you could say I’m prepared for whatever comes next. But why did it have to happen now, though? Why can’t it wait until tomorrow? Or better yet, why can’t it ever happen at all? It’s always the same, someone getting hurt because of me. It never ends well, does it? I can feel it building up inside me, waiting to explode again. But I won’t let it. No way. I’ll keep everything together, even if it kills me. It’s not fair, really. Things aren’t supposed to turn out like this. They’re not meant to get this bad. But they do, and here we are, stuck in this mess. Maybe things will change soon. Maybe someday we’ll find our way back to where we were before. But until then, I’ll try to stay strong, for everyone’s sake. Because I know what happens when people give up, when they lose hope. Triggering Event: He opened his email to find another rejection from a magazine he'd pitched for years. His reflection in the monitor showed the lines etched deeper around his eyes, a silent witness to decades of deadlines and deadline-induced divorces. He clicked "delete," feeling like he'd done the same with his ambitions long ago.

But no, they're too busy with someone else's genius who probably looks like a supermodel. I swear, I've been sending them pitches for years, and this is how it ends? Rejection after rejection, each one a fresh reminder that I'll never make it. They don't even have the decency to send a polite reply. Just fucking delete, right? Like they care about me at all. Well, fuck you! You think you can just ignore me and get away with it? I've worked hard for these rejections, pouring my heart into every pitch, only to be met with silence. Now I'm going to have to deal with another round of disappointment. I wish I could just go back in time and avoid all this shit. Triggering Event: In the middle of her shift at the boutique, she watched as a younger woman, barely out of college, effortlessly charmed a group of well-dressed ladies with stories of her recent European vacation. She caught sight of the new designer shoes they were admiring, the same pair she had coveted but couldn't justify buying on her fixed income. As they laughed together, she felt a pang in her chest, realizing how much she missed that carefree sense of abundance and belonging.
Generated Assessment: She's always been the kind of girl who gets lost in the background, especially when it comes to things like fashion. I mean, I've known her since we were kids growing up in the same neighborhood, and while she was never the prettiest kid around, there was just something about her style that didn't quite fit. It wasn't ugly by any means, but it wasn't exactly... fashionable either? Anyway, this job at the boutique isn't really her thing, and I don't blame her one bit. When you're working for minimum wage, you can't afford fancy clothes, let alone keep them looking brand new. But still, watching her stand there, trying so hard to be part of the conversation, made me feel... off. Like something inside me just shifted, and suddenly everything seemed different. We'd grown up together, but now she looked more like someone from another world, someone who knew things I could only dream of understanding. The way those women were laughing, talking about their trips to Europe and exotic destinations, it was like I was witnessing a whole different life right before my eyes. And then I saw the shoes - those beautiful, high-end heels she'd been eyeing all along, the ones she said were "too expensive" for her budget. I couldn't help but wonder if maybe she was just... pretending? Pretending to be someone else? It hit me like a ton of bricks. Why would anyone pretend to be someone they're not

Triggering Event: She felt her cheeks flush as she realized she had accidentally handed the same customer their change twice, revealing the paltry amount left in the till after a day of heavy discounting. The customer smirked, and she quickly looked away, avoiding eye contact with the queue of waiting customers who had witnessed her mistake.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I’m so done with people being oblivious to their own mistakes. Like, seriously? They can’t even admit when they screw up? That’s so immature. It’s just one little thing—my god, how can you be so careless? She probably has some kind of mental disorder or something. This is like, the third time this week she's messed up. And I'm pretty sure it wasn't an accident either. She must have done it on purpose. Honestly, if I saw someone acting like this again, I’d lose my mind. It doesn't matter what happened before; all that matters is now. So yeah, whatever happened at work doesn’t matter because we’re here and right now...this happens. Anyway, since you’ve been doing such a great job of messing up today, why don’t you try making it worse by asking for more money back? See if anyone notices your incompetence. Maybe then you’ll realize that maybe you're not the smartest person in the room. Just saying.

Triggering Event: She woke up alone in their shared studio, the cold autumn light filtering through the large windows she'd once loved. His canvas, untouched for weeks, stood propped against the wall like a silent reproach. She picked up her brush, dipped it into the faded blue paint that was once his favorite, and tried to capture the essence of his smile. But all that came out was a blur of tears on the canvas.
Generated Assessment: She's always been too close to him. She knew what he wanted from his art. The way he'd layer colors and textures, blending emotions with every stroke. He wanted his paintings to tell stories, but I think she took them too literally. She saw the emotional depth, but missed the technical skill that made each piece unique. Now, she's just trying to fill space with a vague attempt at capturing his smile. It doesn't matter if the painting looks good; it's about the story behind it. If she can't see that, then maybe she never really understood him. But honestly, I'm tired of watching her try to recreate his style. She thinks she can do better, but she misses the essence of what made his work special. Her paintings are just...fine. They don't have the same energy as his canvases. And now, I'm stuck dealing with the mess she's made, cleaning up her paints and brushes while pretending to be okay. Maybe I'll take a break and let her figure this out herself, but until then, I need some time to myself. This is why we broke up, after all. She couldn't handle the pressure of being an artist, and now I'm left to pick up the pieces of her broken dreams. I guess I'll just keep my distance, let her learn from her mistakes, and hope she gets it eventually. But man, it hurts seeing her struggle like this. She needs to remember that art isn’t

Triggering Event: She found his favorite pipe in the attic, untouched since he'd passed five years ago.

Stop acting like this. You can't just sit there, staring at the pipe, thinking about everything. That's not how you process your emotions; you need to move forward. Triggering Event: In the quiet of her lab, she heard his voice again in her mind's ear, as clear as if he were standing beside her. "You're just a glorified lab tech," he'd sneered during their last fight. She looked at the microscope slides, meticulously prepared by her own hands, and felt a surge of spiteful determination. Today, she would publish her findings without checking with him first, just to watch his face when he realized she hadn't needed his approval after all.

Well, let me tell you something, pal: life isn't a fucking video game where you get to level up whenever you want. It's hard work, and if you can't handle it, then maybe you shouldn't be here. You know exactly what I'm talking about. Every time we talk, you find a way to twist my words, make me look like an idiot, and act like you're better than everyone else just because you have a few degrees behind your name. But let me tell you something, you're not going to win this game. I've had enough of your shit, and today's the day I take back control.
